title: Topeak Nano Shock Pump Review: Stripped Down Functionality – John Watson
content:
John’s very mindful of his every-ride carry kit and is ever intrigued by small tools and pumps. During our Sea Otter Reportage, we came across the Topeak Nano Shock pump. This minimal pump has become part of John’s kit and he’s penned a nano review for you to check out below…

Topeak Nano Shock Quick Hits

  • MSRP: $32.95
  • Colors: Olive drab
  • Head: Pressure-Rite shock valve
  • Material: Aluminum
  • Max Pressure: 300 psi / 20 bar
  • Size: 13.5 x 3.2 x 1.6 cm
  • Weight: 56 g (confirmed)
  • Volume per stroke: 4.7 cc
  • Features: Pressure-Rite Valve, Flexible Rotating Hose

Size

The Topeak Nano Shock is by far the smallest shock pump I’ve seen. It measures 5.25 “when closed at its widest and 8.25” when open. It achieves this compact size and weight by omitting both a gauge and a pressure-release/purge/check valve. On a recent ride with the Kona Hei Hei I’m reviewing, it was very useful when dialing in the air pressure on the fork and shock on the light and playful XC platform.

The Nano Shock pump also features a 360º swivel hose, which makes on-the-fly adjustment easy regardless of shock orientation.

Correct Pressure

I’ve found this pump to be very useful when riding new suspension components and dialing in the correct air pressure. Setting sag is a simple procedure, but sometimes you have to make adjustments while on a ride. Too much air and you’re missing out on travel. Too little air, and your fork will dive into corners and lack support. Finding that plush and supportive feel relies on having the correct sag set.

Forks and shocks lose some pressure when you screw on a shock pump is screwed on. This is because the air pressure distributes itself over the larger volume with the pump attached. At lower pressures, it’s not as big of a loss, but at higher pressures, it can really add up. Expect around 2-3 psi of loss on a fork with lower pressures around the 100 psi mark and 5-8 psi on the shock at higher pressures around and above 200 psi.

Yet, this doesn’t matter when setting your sag.

The myth that shock pumps release air pressure from the fork or shock when they are removed has long been propagated. But the truth is, air loss doesn’t occur from the shock or fork, no matter how slowly you unscrew a shock pump or whether it has a manual check valve, an “invention” that came about because of this myth. Your shock or fork is not losing air; your pump hose is. This is why gauges are unnecessary for setting sag and why the o-ring on your shock or fork is the best indicator of correct air pressure.

Functionality

However, I’ve found that some Topeak shock pumps can experience pressure loss due to operator error. If you don’t unscrew the Pressure-Rite knurled control ring far enough before unscrewing the head, you will indeed lose some pressure. So, make sure you completely back off the control ring when unthreading this pump. As you add more air, check your sag to ensure you are meeting the manufacturer’s recommendation. If you need to release air, carefully press an Allen key head onto the Schrader valve to slightly purge extra air.

This is why measuring sag is still the best practice for zeroing in on your fork or shock’s correct air pressure, and why gauges and check valves add unnecessary complexity when making slight adjustments.

To dial in your sag with the Nano Shock pump, simply leave the pump attached until you achieve the correct sag measurement. Then, remove the pump as directed, being mindful of backing the knurled ring out completely. Your air chamber pressure is unaffected, and your fork and shock are now ready to dial in rebound and compression, if applicable.

Overall, the Nano Shock pump’s size makes it desirable. It has stripped the unnecessary gauge and purge/check valve, as it’s meant to be used for small adjustments on the trail. Keeping it in your every-ride carry kit has a negligible impact on space or weight.

Pros

  • Olive drab
  • Small
  • Compact
  • Adds air ;-)

Cons

  • No purge value (you don’t need one)
  • No gauge (you don’t need one)

If you’d like to try one out, roll over to your local bike shop and ask them to order one! Check out more at Topeak.
